repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Third Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project is
            seen as satisfactory, with a sustainable likelihood, and
            substantial institutional development impacts, where both
            the Bank, and Borrower performances are rated satisfactory.
            Key lessons stress the effectiveness of a single-tranche
            operation in addressing specific issues, and providing
            limited budget support to the Government (in the context of
            a difficult policy dialogue), for it allowed time to build
            consensus on the reform agenda, while avoiding the
            requirements of conditionality-driven operations. Moreover,
            the effective timing of the project's financial
            assistance - tied to the budget cycle - provided
            compensatory financing for a reform program, as well as the
            availability of funds, for the Government's fiscal year
            2000 to be included in budgetary planning. Given the nature
            of adjustment lending, it is appropriate to focus on the
            Government's overall use of resources, rather than
            specific uses of Bank funds, which addresses the need for
            sound knowledge on the country's public financial
            management. The project was thus instrumental in preparing
            the analytical work, and in supporting policy reforms, and
            institutional changes needed to improve financial
            accountability, paving the way for the Country Procurement
            Assessment Report, and upcoming Country Financial
            Accountability Assessment. The long-term transition process,
            will benefit from this initial effort, particularly from the
            project's tax, and trade reform, which created an
            environment conducive to efficient private sector
            investment, and growth.

repnme.cdata!:
Burkina Faso - Third Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC) Project is an integral part of the Bank's
            strategy to help Burkina Faso to consolidate recent gains in
            macroeconomic management and to move beyond stabilization to
            deeper structural reforms and sustained economic growth. The
            Credit assists the Government in gaining competitiveness; in
            stimulating resource mobilization, private investment flows,
            and external trade; and in improving efficiency. This one
            tranche operation, fully consistent with the new Country
            Assistance Strategy under preparation, would be the second
            in a series of such operations to support a reform program
            aimed at: 1) enhancing the competitiveness of the economy to
            substantially raise growth rates over the medium term and
            alleviate poverty; 2) improving public finance management,
            particularly concerning tax policy and the use of public
            resources; and 3) completing the third phase of the common
            external tariff (CET) adopted by the West African Economic
            and Monetary Union (WAEMU) on January 1, 2000. When fully
            implemented, the reform program could result in improved
            allocative efficiency that could raise real growth, and as a
            result of faster growth and improved social service
            delivery, bring about a substantial decline in poverty.
            Also, by focusing on revenue mobilization and the efficient
            reallocation of public resources towards priority areas, the
            operation is expected to ensure that these key sectors would
            not suffer from budgetary cuts during the transition.
